item.title: University of the People
item.description:
‎Academic programs: Added information about admission and coursework.

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 77: Line 77:
 
* Associate of Science Degree (A.S.) in Computer Science
  
* Associate of Science Degree (A.S.) in Computer Science
 
The UoPeople is in the process of developing MBA programmes and a health sciences programme.<ref>{{cite web|last=Murray | first=Seb | url=http://www.businessbecause.com/news/mba-distance-learning/3039/mooc-maker-competes-with-bschools-with-tuition-free-online-mba | title=Digital university to compete with B-schools with tuitino-free MBAs | publisher=BusinessBecause | date=2015-01-14 | accessdate=2015-07-20}}</ref>
  
The UoPeople is in the process of developing MBA programmes and a health sciences programme.<ref>{{cite web|last=Murray | first=Seb | url=http://www.businessbecause.com/news/mba-distance-learning/3039/mooc-maker-competes-with-bschools-with-tuition-free-online-mba | title=Digital university to compete with B-schools with tuitino-free MBAs | publisher=BusinessBecause | date=2015-01-14 | accessdate=2015-07-20}}</ref>
  +
  +
There are only three requirements to be admitted into the university: a high-school diploma, English proficiency, and Internet access. After completing some basic liberal-arts curriculum, students can dive into their specialty. Each course, which has been designed by an advisory board of academics and practitioners, consists of individual homework assignments and active online discussion. Class size is usually between 20-30 students from all over the world<ref>{{cite web|last1=Snyder|first1=Anne|title=Higher Ed, Lower Costs|url=http://www.philanthropyroundtable.org/topic/excellence_in_philanthropy/higher_ed_lower_costs|website=Philanthropy|publisher=Philanthropy Roundtable|accessdate=14 December 2015}}</ref>.
   
 
UoPeople is the only OER university in the world, i.e. every course makes use of [[open educational resources]] and students don't need to pay for any textbooks.<ref name=oer>{{cite web|last=Reed |first=Matt |url=https://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/confessions-community-college-dean/oer-retention-initiative |title=OER as Retention Initiative | Confessions of a Community College Dean |publisher=Insidehighered.com |date=2015-02-23 |accessdate=2015-03-15}}</ref>
  
UoPeople is the only OER university in the world, i.e. every course makes use of [[open educational resources]] and students don't need to pay for any textbooks.<ref name=oer>{{cite web|last=Reed |first=Matt |url=https://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/confessions-community-college-dean/oer-retention-initiative |title=OER as Retention Initiative | Confessions of a Community College Dean |publisher=Insidehighered.com |date=2015-02-23 |accessdate=2015-03-15}}</ref>

'''''The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2''''' is a 2015 American [[Epic film|epic]] [[dystopia]]n [[Science fiction film|science fiction]] [[war film]] directed by [[Francis Lawrence]], with a screenplay by [[Peter Craig]] and [[Danny Strong]]. It is the fourth and final installment in [[The Hunger Games (film series)|''The Hunger Games'' film series]], and the second of two films based on the novel ''[[Mockingjay]]'', the final book in [[The Hunger Games trilogy|''The Hunger Games'' trilogy]], by [[Suzanne Collins]]. Produced by [[Nina Jacobson]] and Jon Kilik, and distributed by [[Lionsgate]], the film features an [[ensemble cast]] that includes [[Jennifer Lawrence]], [[Josh Hutcherson]], [[Liam Hemsworth]], [[Woody Harrelson]], [[Elizabeth Banks]], [[Julianne Moore]], [[Sam Claflin]], [[Jena Malone]], [[Philip Seymour Hoffman]] (in his final film role), and [[Donald Sutherland]]. The first part of the ''Mockingjay'' adaptation, ''[[The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1]]'', was released on November 21, 2014.
  
'''''The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2''''' is a 2015 American [[Epic film|epic]] [[dystopia]]n [[Science fiction film|science fiction]] [[war film]] directed by [[Francis Lawrence]], with a screenplay by [[Peter Craig]] and [[Danny Strong]]. It is the fourth and final installment in [[The Hunger Games (film series)|''The Hunger Games'' film series]], and the second of two films based on the novel ''[[Mockingjay]]'', the final book in [[The Hunger Games trilogy|''The Hunger Games'' trilogy]], by [[Suzanne Collins]]. Produced by [[Nina Jacobson]] and Jon Kilik, and distributed by [[Lionsgate]], the film features an [[ensemble cast]] that includes [[Jennifer Lawrence]], [[Josh Hutcherson]], [[Liam Hemsworth]], [[Woody Harrelson]], [[Elizabeth Banks]], [[Julianne Moore]], [[Sam Claflin]], [[Jena Malone]], [[Philip Seymour Hoffman]] (in his final film role), and [[Donald Sutherland]]. The first part of the ''Mockingjay'' adaptation, ''[[The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1]]'', was released on November 21, 2014.
Line 216: Line 216:
   
 
===Box office===
  
===Box office===
−
{{Asof|2015|12|13|df=US}}, ''The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2'' has grossed $244.5 million in North America and $320.1 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $564.6 million, against a budget of $160 million.<ref name=BOM /> Its worldwide opening of $247.2 million is the [[List of highest-grossing openings for films|twenty-fourth biggest of all time]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/world/worldwideopenings.htm|title=WORLDWIDE OPENINGS|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=November 22, 2015}}</ref>
 +
{{Asof|2015|12|13|df=US}}, ''The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2'' has grossed $244.6 million in North America and $320.1 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $564.7 million, against a budget of $160 million.<ref name=BOM /> Its worldwide opening of $247.2 million is the [[List of highest-grossing openings for films|twenty-fourth biggest of all time]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/world/worldwideopenings.htm|title=WORLDWIDE OPENINGS|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=November 22, 2015}}</ref>

item.title: Lisa Ortiz
item.description:
Updated information.

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 16: Line 16:
 
}}
  
}}
   
−
'''Lisa Ortiz''' (born December 11, 1978) is an [[United States|American]] [[theatre]] and [[voice actor|voice actress]], as well as voice director, best known for her roles in [[English language|English]] [[anime]] adaptations. She is perhaps best known for the roles of the high-elf Deedlit in ''[[Record of Lodoss War]]'', Lina Inverse in ''[[Slayers]]'', and [[Tony Tony Chopper]] in the 4Kids dub of [[One Piece]]. Her extensive résumé also includes the role of [[Amy Rose]] in ''[[Sonic X]]'', and [[Shizuka Kawai|Serenity Wheeler]] in ''[[Yu-Gi-Oh! (second series anime)|Yu-Gi-Oh!]]''. She has voiced Amy Rose in the ''[[List of games featuring Sonic the Hedgehog|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' series of video games from ''[[Shadow the Hedgehog (video game)|Shadow the Hedgehog]]'' to 2010, as the successor to voice actress [[Jennifer Douillard]], who voiced the character from ''[[Sonic Adventure]]'' to ''[[Sonic Advance 3]]''. Living in [[New York City]] and frequently meeting people who speak other languages, Ortiz helps in creating the dialect voices for which she is well recognized.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20071005181044/http://www.fansview.com/2000b/051200f.htm Anime Central – Day One – Lisa Ortiz]. A Fan's View of Anime Conventions – Anime Central 2000, interview from 2000-05-12</ref> Ortiz holds a [[Bachelor of Fine Arts|BFA]] in theatre from [[Hofstra University]]. She has appeared in titles for [[NYAV Post]], [[4Kids Entertainment]], [[Central Park Media]], [[Funimation Entertainment]], Headline Studios, [[TAJ Productions]], and [[DuArt Film and Video]]. At the 2002 [[Katsucon]] in [[National Harbor, Maryland]], Lisa admitted that her start in voice overs came from her brother stealing her car, which led to series of adventures that led her to meeting a friend to retrieve the car, who then invited her to a casting call for ''[[Record of Lodoss War]]''.
 +
'''Lisa Ortiz''' (born December 11, 1978) is an [[United States|American]] [[theatre]] and [[voice actor|voice actress]], as well as voice director, best known for her roles in [[English language|English]] [[anime]] adaptations. She is perhaps best known for the roles of the high-elf Deedlit in ''[[Record of Lodoss War]]'', Lina Inverse in ''[[Slayers]]'', Oshawatt in [[Pokémon|Pokemon]] and [[Tony Tony Chopper]] in the 4Kids dub of [[One Piece]]. Her extensive résumé also includes the role of [[Amy Rose]] in ''[[Sonic X]]'', and [[Shizuka Kawai|Serenity Wheeler]] in ''[[Yu-Gi-Oh! (second series anime)|Yu-Gi-Oh!]]''. She has voiced Amy Rose in the ''[[List of games featuring Sonic the Hedgehog|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' series of video games from ''[[Shadow the Hedgehog (video game)|Shadow the Hedgehog]]'' to 2010, as the successor to voice actress [[Jennifer Douillard]], who voiced the character from ''[[Sonic Adventure]]'' to ''[[Sonic Advance 3]]''. Living in [[New York City]] and frequently meeting people who speak other languages, Ortiz helps in creating the dialect voices for which she is well recognized.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20071005181044/http://www.fansview.com/2000b/051200f.htm Anime Central – Day One – Lisa Ortiz]. A Fan's View of Anime Conventions – Anime Central 2000, interview from 2000-05-12</ref> Ortiz holds a [[Bachelor of Fine Arts|BFA]] in theatre from [[Hofstra University]]. She has appeared in titles for [[NYAV Post]], [[4Kids Entertainment]], [[Central Park Media]], [[Funimation Entertainment]], Headline Studios, [[TAJ Productions]], and [[DuArt Film and Video]]. At the 2002 [[Katsucon]] in [[National Harbor, Maryland]], Lisa admitted that her start in voice overs came from her brother stealing her car, which led to series of adventures that led her to meeting a friend to retrieve the car, who then invited her to a casting call for ''[[Record of Lodoss War]]''.
   
−
Lisa is the President of Noise of O Productions, LLC an audio post house and has directed for various games and animation, including Pokemon, Modern Combat 5 and Super 4 Playmobil.
+
Lisa is the President of Noise of O Productions, LLC an audio post house and has directed for various games and animation, including [[Pokémon|Pokemon]], [[Modern Combat 5: Blackout|Modern Combat 5]] and [[Super 4 (TV series)|Super 4]] Playmobil.
   
 
She is sometimes assumed to have been a cast member of the Canadian television show ''[[Hillside (TV show)|Fifteen]]'', however, she confirmed in a podcast interview that she did not appear, and that it was actually another Lisa Ortiz.<ref>http://withspecialguest.posterous.com/episode-seven-lisa-ortiz Lisa Ortiz</ref>
  
She is sometimes assumed to have been a cast member of the Canadian television show ''[[Hillside (TV show)|Fifteen]]'', however, she confirmed in a podcast interview that she did not appear, and that it was actually another Lisa Ortiz.<ref>http://withspecialguest.posterous.com/episode-seven-lisa-ortiz Lisa Ortiz</ref>

item.title: Marcus Stroman
item.description:
Can you Figure it Out?

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 45: Line 45:
 
title=Blue Jays assign Marcus Stroman, Ricky Romero to minor league camp|date=March 19, 2014|accessdate=March 19, 2014|work=Buffalo Bisons}}</ref> He was the 2014 Opening Day starting pitcher for the Triple-A [[Buffalo Bisons]].<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.buffalonews.com/sports/bisons-baseball/herds-stroman-has-huge-chip-on-his-shoulder-20140402|title=Herd’s Stroman has huge chip on his shoulder|last=Moritz|first=Amy|work=buffalonews.com|date=April 2, 2014|accessdate=September 8, 2015}}</ref>
  
title=Blue Jays assign Marcus Stroman, Ricky Romero to minor league camp|date=March 19, 2014|accessdate=March 19, 2014|work=Buffalo Bisons}}</ref> He was the 2014 Opening Day starting pitcher for the Triple-A [[Buffalo Bisons]].<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.buffalonews.com/sports/bisons-baseball/herds-stroman-has-huge-chip-on-his-shoulder-20140402|title=Herd’s Stroman has huge chip on his shoulder|last=Moritz|first=Amy|work=buffalonews.com|date=April 2, 2014|accessdate=September 8, 2015}}</ref>
 
 
−
===Major league career===
 +
===Toronto Blue Jays===
−
[[File:Marcus Stroman on September 12, 2015.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Stroman in his 2015 debut]]
 +
====2014 season====
 
Stroman was called up to the Blue Jays on May 3, 2014, after [[Brandon Morrow]] was transferred to the 60-day disabled list.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/05/03/blue-jays-call-up-pitching-prospect-marcus-stroman/|title=Blue Jays call up pitching prospect Marcus Stroman|last=Baer|first=Bill|work=hardballtalk.nbcsports.com|date=May 3, 2014|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> At the time of his call-up, he was considered the organization's number two prospect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20140503&content_id=74213498&notebook_id=74263130&vkey=notebook_tor&c_id=tor|title=Blue Jays' No. 2 prospect Stroman to join 'pen|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|work=MLB.com|date=May 3, 2014|accessdate=May 4, 2014}}</ref> He earned his first MLB victory on May 6, pitching 1{{frac|1|3}} innings in relief of [[Drew Hutchison]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jaysjournal.com/2014/05/06/blue-jays-game-recap-mlb-scores-toronto-blue-jays-philadelphia-phillies/|title=Blue Jays Game Recap: Drew Hutchison Shows Grit|last=Doyle|first=Shaun|work=jaysjournal.com|date=May 6, 2014|accessdate=May 6, 2014}}</ref> Stroman was optioned back to Triple-A Buffalo on May 18, and was recalled on May 30 to make his first Major League start the following day. He pitched six innings and surrendered only one earned run on five hits, striking out six and issuing no walks to earn the win over the [[Kansas City Royals]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/blue-jays-score-7-in-1st-to-thump-royals/|title=Blue Jays score 7 runs in 1st to crush Royals|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=May 31, 2014|accessdate=May 31, 2014}}</ref> On August 9, Stroman pitched nine innings for the first time in his career, but came away with a no-decision as the Blue Jays defeated the [[Detroit Tigers]] 3–2 in extra innings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/gameday/index.jsp?gid=2014_08_09_detmlb_tormlb_1&mode=recap_home&c_id=tor|title=Reimold plays hero with 10th-inning walk-off double|last=Ross|first=Jaime|work=MLB.com|date=August 9, 2014|accessdate=August 9, 2014}}</ref> He would earn his first [[complete game]] and [[Shutout (baseball)|shutout]] on September 8, needing only 93 pitches to beat the [[Chicago Cubs]], 8–0. Stroman yielded only three hits and at one point had retired 19 consecutive batters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/stroman-pitches-first-cg-shutout-in-jays-win/|title=Stroman pitches first CG shutout in Jays' win|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=September 8, 2014|accessdate=September 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/stroman-more-than-a-flash-in-the-pan-for-jays/|title=Stroman more than a flash in the pan for Jays|last=Davidi|first=Shi|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=September 8, 2014|accessdate=September 8, 2014}}</ref>
 
Stroman was called up to the Blue Jays on May 3, 2014, after [[Brandon Morrow]] was transferred to the 60-day disabled list.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/05/03/blue-jays-call-up-pitching-prospect-marcus-stroman/|title=Blue Jays call up pitching prospect Marcus Stroman|last=Baer|first=Bill|work=hardballtalk.nbcsports.com|date=May 3, 2014|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> At the time of his call-up, he was considered the organization's number two prospect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20140503&content_id=74213498&notebook_id=74263130&vkey=notebook_tor&c_id=tor|title=Blue Jays' No. 2 prospect Stroman to join 'pen|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|work=MLB.com|date=May 3, 2014|accessdate=May 4, 2014}}</ref> He earned his first MLB victory on May 6, pitching 1{{frac|1|3}} innings in relief of [[Drew Hutchison]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jaysjournal.com/2014/05/06/blue-jays-game-recap-mlb-scores-toronto-blue-jays-philadelphia-phillies/|title=Blue Jays Game Recap: Drew Hutchison Shows Grit|last=Doyle|first=Shaun|work=jaysjournal.com|date=May 6, 2014|accessdate=May 6, 2014}}</ref> Stroman was optioned back to Triple-A Buffalo on May 18, and was recalled on May 30 to make his first Major League start the following day. He pitched six innings and surrendered only one earned run on five hits, striking out six and issuing no walks to earn the win over the [[Kansas City Royals]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/blue-jays-score-7-in-1st-to-thump-royals/|title=Blue Jays score 7 runs in 1st to crush Royals|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=May 31, 2014|accessdate=May 31, 2014}}</ref> On August 9, Stroman pitched nine innings for the first time in his career, but came away with a no-decision as the Blue Jays defeated the [[Detroit Tigers]] 3–2 in extra innings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/gameday/index.jsp?gid=2014_08_09_detmlb_tormlb_1&mode=recap_home&c_id=tor|title=Reimold plays hero with 10th-inning walk-off double|last=Ross|first=Jaime|work=MLB.com|date=August 9, 2014|accessdate=August 9, 2014}}</ref> He would earn his first [[complete game]] and [[Shutout (baseball)|shutout]] on September 8, needing only 93 pitches to beat the [[Chicago Cubs]], 8–0. Stroman yielded only three hits and at one point had retired 19 consecutive batters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/stroman-pitches-first-cg-shutout-in-jays-win/|title=Stroman pitches first CG shutout in Jays' win|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=September 8, 2014|accessdate=September 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/stroman-more-than-a-flash-in-the-pan-for-jays/|title=Stroman more than a flash in the pan for Jays|last=Davidi|first=Shi|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=September 8, 2014|accessdate=September 8, 2014}}</ref>
   
 
On September 17, Stroman was suspended six games and fined an undisclosed amount for intentionally throwing at [[Caleb Joseph]] during a game against the [[Baltimore Orioles]]. Immediately following the announcement, he filed an appeal of the suspension.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tsn.ca/mlb/story/?id=462010|title=MLB suspends Jays' Stroman six games; appeal launched|work=TSN.ca|date=September 17, 2014|accessdate=September 17, 2014}}</ref> On September 21, Stroman dropped his appeal, and MLB reduced his suspension to five games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/stroman-gets-six-game-suspension-cut-to-five/|title=Stroman gets six-game suspension cut to five|last=Davidi|first=Shi|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=September 21, 2014|accessdate=September 21, 2014}}</ref> It was announced shortly afterward that upon his return from the suspension, he would be moved to the bullpen for the remainder of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.nationalpost.com/2014/09/23/toronto-blue-jays-rookie-marcus-stromans-year-as-a-starter-comes-to-a-close/|title=Toronto Blue Jays rookie Marcus Stroman's year as a starter comes to a close|last=Koreen|first=Eric|work=sports.nationalpost.com|date=September 23, 2014|accessdate=September 23, 2014}}</ref> Stroman pitched four innings in relief of Drew Hutchison's final start of the season on September 26, and earned his first career [[Save (baseball)|save]]. He did not appear in the final two games of the Blue Jays season, and finished 2014 with an 11–6 record, 3.65 ERA, 111 strikeouts, and a 1.17 WHIP in 130{{frac|2|3}} innings pitched.<ref name="BR">{{citeweb|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/s/stromma01.shtml|title=Marcus Stroman Statistics & History|work=[[Baseball-Reference]]|accessdate=September 28, 2014}}</ref>
  
On September 17, Stroman was suspended six games and fined an undisclosed amount for intentionally throwing at [[Caleb Joseph]] during a game against the [[Baltimore Orioles]]. Immediately following the announcement, he filed an appeal of the suspension.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tsn.ca/mlb/story/?id=462010|title=MLB suspends Jays' Stroman six games; appeal launched|work=TSN.ca|date=September 17, 2014|accessdate=September 17, 2014}}</ref> On September 21, Stroman dropped his appeal, and MLB reduced his suspension to five games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/stroman-gets-six-game-suspension-cut-to-five/|title=Stroman gets six-game suspension cut to five|last=Davidi|first=Shi|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=September 21, 2014|accessdate=September 21, 2014}}</ref> It was announced shortly afterward that upon his return from the suspension, he would be moved to the bullpen for the remainder of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.nationalpost.com/2014/09/23/toronto-blue-jays-rookie-marcus-stromans-year-as-a-starter-comes-to-a-close/|title=Toronto Blue Jays rookie Marcus Stroman's year as a starter comes to a close|last=Koreen|first=Eric|work=sports.nationalpost.com|date=September 23, 2014|accessdate=September 23, 2014}}</ref> Stroman pitched four innings in relief of Drew Hutchison's final start of the season on September 26, and earned his first career [[Save (baseball)|save]]. He did not appear in the final two games of the Blue Jays season, and finished 2014 with an 11–6 record, 3.65 ERA, 111 strikeouts, and a 1.17 WHIP in 130{{frac|2|3}} innings pitched.<ref name="BR">{{citeweb|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/s/stromma01.shtml|title=Marcus Stroman Statistics & History|work=[[Baseball-Reference]]|accessdate=September 28, 2014}}</ref>
   
  +
====2015 season====
  +
[[File:Marcus Stroman on September 12, 2015.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Stroman in his 2015 debut]]
 
On October 6, 2014, Stroman announced through his [[Twitter]] account that he would change his uniform number from 54 to 6 in honor of his grandmother.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/blue-jays-sp-stroman-changing-to-no-6-in-2015/|title=Blue Jays SP Stroman changing to No. 6 in 2015|last=McKenna|first=Ryan|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=October 6, 2014|accessdate=October 6, 2014}}</ref> During [[spring training]] in 2015, Stroman tore the [[anterior cruciate ligament]] in his left knee, and was seemingly ruled out for 2015.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2015/03/10/blue-jays-lose-marcus-stroman-for-the-season-with-a-torn-acl/|title=Blue Jays lose Marcus Stroman for the season with a torn ACL|last=Gleeman|first=Aaron|work=hardballtalk.nbcsports.com|date=March 10, 2015|accessdate=March 10, 2015}}</ref> He underwent a successful surgery, performed by [[James Andrews (physician)|Dr. James Andrews]], to repair his ACL.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2015/03/19/marcus-stroman-undergoes-knee-surgery/|title=Marcus Stroman undergoes knee surgery|last=Short|first=D.J.|work=hardballtalk.nbcsports.com|date=March 19, 2015|accessdate=March 30, 2015}}</ref> Stroman was placed on the 60-day disabled list on April 5.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2015/04/blue-jays-designate-juan-oramas-for-assignment.html|title=Blue Jays Designate Juan Oramas For Assignment|last=Creech|first=Edward|work=mlbtraderumors.com|date=April 5, 2015|accessdate=April 5, 2015}}</ref> While receiving rehab Stroman returned to Duke University to finish his degree, majoring in Sociology with a minor in Markets and Management Studies.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://m.mlb.com/news/article/120293802/jays-marcus-stroman-to-finish-duke-degree-while-rehabbing-knee|title=Stroman to finish Duke degree while rehabbing knee|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|work=MLB.com|accessdate=September 23, 2015}}</ref>
  
On October 6, 2014, Stroman announced through his [[Twitter]] account that he would change his uniform number from 54 to 6 in honor of his grandmother.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/blue-jays-sp-stroman-changing-to-no-6-in-2015/|title=Blue Jays SP Stroman changing to No. 6 in 2015|last=McKenna|first=Ryan|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=October 6, 2014|accessdate=October 6, 2014}}</ref> During [[spring training]] in 2015, Stroman tore the [[anterior cruciate ligament]] in his left knee, and was seemingly ruled out for 2015.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2015/03/10/blue-jays-lose-marcus-stroman-for-the-season-with-a-torn-acl/|title=Blue Jays lose Marcus Stroman for the season with a torn ACL|last=Gleeman|first=Aaron|work=hardballtalk.nbcsports.com|date=March 10, 2015|accessdate=March 10, 2015}}</ref> He underwent a successful surgery, performed by [[James Andrews (physician)|Dr. James Andrews]], to repair his ACL.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2015/03/19/marcus-stroman-undergoes-knee-surgery/|title=Marcus Stroman undergoes knee surgery|last=Short|first=D.J.|work=hardballtalk.nbcsports.com|date=March 19, 2015|accessdate=March 30, 2015}}</ref> Stroman was placed on the 60-day disabled list on April 5.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2015/04/blue-jays-designate-juan-oramas-for-assignment.html|title=Blue Jays Designate Juan Oramas For Assignment|last=Creech|first=Edward|work=mlbtraderumors.com|date=April 5, 2015|accessdate=April 5, 2015}}</ref> While receiving rehab Stroman returned to Duke University to finish his degree, majoring in Sociology with a minor in Markets and Management Studies.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://m.mlb.com/news/article/120293802/jays-marcus-stroman-to-finish-duke-degree-while-rehabbing-knee|title=Stroman to finish Duke degree while rehabbing knee|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|work=MLB.com|accessdate=September 23, 2015}}</ref>

item.title: Chasing Shadows (album)
item.description:
← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 28: Line 28:
 
''Chasing Shadows'' was regarded by the band as a departure from their two prior albums, ''[[Land (The Comsat Angels album)|Land]]'' and ''[[7 Day Weekend (album)|7 Day Weekend]]'', which were produced by [[Jive Records]]. During a 1997 interview, frontman [[Stephen Fellows|Steve Fellows]] agreed with a suggestion that ''Chasing Shadows'' displayed his best vocal performance, adding: "I liked Rockfield, where we recorded ''Chasing Shadows'' cos it was very informal. We played mostly live, with vocals added later. ''[[Sleep No More (The Comsat Angels album)|Sleep No More]]'' was done live – the feel, capturing the moment. Obviously the Jive albums weren't done like that – assembled by machines in another room while we watched television and ate fruit." <ref>Step Off, interviews, Stephen Fellows interviewed by Tony Kinson 13/3/97 [http://www.comsatangels.net/]</ref>
  
''Chasing Shadows'' was regarded by the band as a departure from their two prior albums, ''[[Land (The Comsat Angels album)|Land]]'' and ''[[7 Day Weekend (album)|7 Day Weekend]]'', which were produced by [[Jive Records]]. We played mostly live, with vocals added later. ''[[Sleep No More (The Comsat Angels album)|Sleep No More]]'' was done live – the feel, capturing the moment. Obviously the Jive albums weren't done like that – assembled by machines in another room while we watched television and ate fruit." <ref>Step Off, interviews, Stephen Fellows interviewed by Tony Kinson 13/3/97 [http://www.comsatangels.net/]</ref>
   
−
''Chasing Shadows'' was reissued by Edsel Records in November 2015 as part of a two-CD set which also included the 1990 album [[Fire on the Moon (Dream Command album)|Fire on the Moon]], which was recorded by the band using the name [[Dream Command]].
 +
''Chasing Shadows'' was reissued by Edsel Records in November 2015 as part of a two-CD set which also included the 1990 album ''[[Fire on the Moon (Dream Command album)|Fire on the Moon]]'', which was recorded by the band using the name [[Dream Command]].

item.description:

Line 73: Line 73:
 
The film is based on [[Patricia Highsmith]]'s 1952 semi-autobiographical novel ''[[The Price of Salt]]'', originally published under the pseudonym Claire Morgan, and published in 1990 as ''Carol'' under Highsmith's own name.<ref>{{cite book|title=Anxiety and Evil in the Writings of Patricia Highsmith|last=Peters|first=Fiona|publisher=[[Ashgate Publishing]]|page=93, 127|isbn=1409478912}}</ref><ref name="passion project"/> The film was in development for over 11 years by [[Film4 Productions]] and Number 9 Films.<ref name=standard>{{cite web|url=http://www.standard.co.uk/showbiz/patricia-highsmiths-lesbian-tale-brought-to-the-screen-after-11year-battle-9385772.html|title=Patricia Highsmith’s lesbian tale brought to the screen after 11-year battle|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|first=Louise|last=Jury|date=May 16, 2014|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref> [[Phyllis Nagy]], who was a friend of Highsmith, wrote the first draft of the script in 1996.<ref name="UK film">{{cite web|url=http://weareukfilm.com/news/2015-05-17/talent-talk-carol|title=TALENT TALK: CAROL|website=We Are UK Film|date=May 17, 2015|accessdate=June 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite interview|interviewer=David Poland|subject=Phyllis Nagy|title=DP/30 in Cannes: Carol, Phyllis Nagy|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GF60XeySQtI|date=May 22, 2015|program=DP/30: The Oral History Of Hollywood|access-date=May 24, 2015}}</ref> Highsmith had suggested to Nagy she adapt one of her novels.<ref name="Highsmith">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/cannes-todd-haynes-and-writer-phyllis-nagy-talk-carol-glamorous-stars-highsmith-and-more-20150601|title=Cannes: Todd Haynes and Writer Phyllis Nagy Talk 'Carol,' Glamorous Stars, Highsmith and More|work=[[Indiewire]]|publisher=[[SnagFilms]]|first=Anne|last=Thompson|date=June 1, 2015|accessdate=June 1, 2015}}</ref> Nagy decided to adapt the script to ensure its fidelity to the source material, remarking, "I felt a strange responsibility to take it, and to make sure that it wasn’t screwed up in some fundamental way, because she so disliked many of the screen adaptations of her work."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://creativescreenwriting.com/carol-less-is-more-when-adapting-highsmith/|title=Carol: “Less is More” when adapting Highsmith|last=Park|first=Jennie E.|date=December 2, 2015|work=Creative Screenwriting|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> British producer [[Elizabeth Karlsen]] of Number 9 Films came across Nagy's screenplay in 2004. Nagy had spent 14 years trying to get the film made prior to Karlsen convincing Highsmith's estate to sign over the copyright to her in 2011.<ref name="passion project">{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/14/carol-film-cannes-karlsen-cate-blanchett|title=Passion project: meet the indie super-producer behind Cannes hot ticket Carol|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=May 14, 2015|accessdate=May 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name="UK film"/>

under Highsmith's own name.<ref>{{cite book|title=Anxiety and Evil in the Writings of Patricia Highsmith|last=Peters|first=Fiona|publisher=[[Ashgate Publishing]]|page=93, 127|isbn=1409478912}}</ref><ref name="passion project"/> The film was in development for over 11 years by [[Film4 Productions]] and Number 9 Films.<ref name=standard>{{cite web|url=http://www.standard.co.uk/showbiz/patricia-highsmiths-lesbian-tale-brought-to-the-screen-after-11year-battle-9385772.html|title=Patricia Highsmith’s lesbian tale brought to the screen after 11-year battle|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|first=Louise|last=Jury|date=May 16, 2014|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref> [[Phyllis Nagy]], who was a friend of Highsmith, wrote the first draft of the script in 1996.<ref name="UK film">{{cite web|url=http://weareukfilm.com/news/2015-05-17/talent-talk-carol|title=TALENT TALK: CAROL|website=We Are UK Film|date=May 17, 2015|accessdate=June 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite interview|interviewer=David Poland|subject=Phyllis Nagy|title=DP/30 in Cannes: Carol, Phyllis Nagy|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GF60XeySQtI|date=May 22, 2015|program=DP/30: The Oral History Of Hollywood|access-date=May 24, 2015}}</ref> Highsmith had suggested to Nagy she adapt one of her novels.<ref name="Highsmith">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/thompsononhollywood/cannes-todd-haynes-and-writer-phyllis-nagy-talk-carol-glamorous-stars-highsmith-and-more-20150601|title=Cannes: Todd Haynes and Writer Phyllis Nagy Talk 'Carol,' Glamorous Stars, Highsmith and More|work=[[Indiewire]]|publisher=[[SnagFilms]]|first=Anne|last=Thompson|date=June 1, 2015|accessdate=June 1, 2015}}</ref> Nagy decided to adapt the script to ensure its fidelity to the source material, remarking, "I felt a strange responsibility to take it, and to make sure that it wasn’t screwed up in some fundamental way, because she so disliked many of the screen adaptations of her work."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://creativescreenwriting.com/carol-less-is-more-when-adapting-highsmith/|title=Carol: “Less is More” when adapting Highsmith|last=Park|first=Jennie E.|date=December 2, 2015|work=Creative Screenwriting|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> British producer [[Elizabeth Karlsen]] of Number 9 Films came across Nagy's screenplay in 2004. Nagy had spent 14 years trying to get the film made prior to Karlsen convincing Highsmith's estate to sign over the copyright to her in 2011.<ref name="passion project">{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/14/carol-film-cannes-karlsen-cate-blanchett|title=Passion project: meet the indie super-producer behind Cannes hot ticket Carol|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=May 14, 2015|accessdate=May 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name="UK film"/>
   
−
One of the challenges of adapting the novel was translating the subjective and limited [[Narration#Third-person|third-person]] point of view whereby Carol is largely seen through Therese's fanatical prism. Nagy decided to split the point of view and shift perspective from Therese to Carol, as "the point of view is always with the more vulnerable party". She made Therese a photographer instead of a set designer, allowing her "to be seen moving from objects to people", which Nagy likened to Highsmith as Therese is a "clear stand-in" for the author.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/nov/12/how-patricia-highsmiths-carol-became-a-film-lesbianism-is-not-an-issue|title=How Patricia Highsmith's Carol became a film: 'Lesbianism is not an issue. It's a state of normal'|work=The Guardian|date=November 12, 2015|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref> On the universality of the story, Haynes said that the "real determining question is not whether society will accept [Therese's] feelings or not; it’s, will this person return her love or not? ... That is what transcends the class of love, or the period in which it’s occurring".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/12/todd-haynes-carol-interview-director-oscars-1201664625/|title=Todd Haynes On 'Carol,' Cate And Their Refusal To Pander|work=Deadline|date=December 12, 2015|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref>
 +
One of the challenges of adapting the novel was translating the subjective and limited [[Narration#Third-person|third-person]] point of view whereby Carol is largely seen through Therese's fanatical prism. Nagy decided to split the point of view and shift perspective from Therese to Carol, as "the point of view is always with the more vulnerable party". She made Therese a photographer instead of a set designer, allowing her "to be seen moving from objects to people", which Nagy likened to Highsmith as Therese is a "clear stand-in" for the author.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/nov/12/how-patricia-highsmiths-carol-became-a-film-lesbianism-is-not-an-issue|title=How Patricia Highsmith's Carol became a film: 'Lesbianism is not an issue. It's a state of normal'|work=The Guardian|date=November 12, 2015|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref> On the universality of the story, Haynes said that the "real determining question is not whether society will accept [Therese's] feelings or not; it’s, will this person return her love or not? ... That is what transcends the class of love, or the period in which it’s occurring".<ref name="Utichi">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/12/todd-haynes-carol-interview-director-oscars-1201664625/|title=Todd Haynes On 'Carol,' Cate And Their Refusal To Pander|work=Deadline|date=December 12, 2015|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref>
   
 
At the [[BFI London Film Festival]], Phyllis Nagy said she titled the film ''Carol'', not ''The Price of Salt'', because Highsmith herself had changed the title to ''Carol'' when the novel was republished, and she also "liked the sort of strange, obsessive nature of calling it by someone's name." There were later other discussions with Haynes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ohdus0fSNKs|title=Carol Press Conference in Full - Cate Blanchett & Rooney Mara|publisher=YouTube|date=October 14, 2015|accessdate=October 19, 2015}}</ref> Haynes said that the film is called ''Carol'' because the novel "is locked into the subjectivity of the younger woman" and Carol is "really the object of desire in the story." "There’s an element of, something aloof about her...something unsettled about [her], that puts Therese and these new feelings...on edge throughout much of the film. That relationship of who’s the object and who’s the subject does shift in the story, but it made sense ultimately that that would be the name for the film.”<ref>{{cite interview|interviewer=[[Noah Cowan]]|subject=Todd Haynes|title=JCCSF - Todd Haynes|url=https://www.jccsf.org/arts-ideas/ondemand/2015-2016-season/todd-haynes/|date=September 24, 2015|program=Arts & Ideas at the Jewish Community Center of San Francisco|access-date=October 19, 2015}}</ref>
  
At the [[BFI London Film Festival]], Phyllis Nagy said she titled the film ''Carol'', not ''The Price of Salt'', because Highsmith herself had changed the title to ''Carol'' when the novel was republished, and she also "liked the sort of strange, obsessive nature of calling it by someone's name." There were later other discussions with Haynes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ohdus0fSNKs|title=Carol Press Conference in Full - Cate Blanchett & Rooney Mara|publisher=YouTube|date=October 14, 2015|accessdate=October 19, 2015}}</ref> Haynes said that the film is called ''Carol'' because the novel "is locked into the subjectivity of the younger woman" and Carol is "really the object of desire in the story." "There’s an element of, something aloof about her...something unsettled about [her], that puts Therese and these new feelings...on edge throughout much of the film. That relationship of who’s the object and who’s the subject does shift in the story, but it made sense ultimately that that would be the name for the film.”<ref>{{cite interview|interviewer=[[Noah Cowan]]|subject=Todd Haynes|title=JCCSF - Todd Haynes|url=https://www.jccsf.org/arts-ideas/ondemand/2015-2016-season/todd-haynes/|date=September 24, 2015|program=Arts & Ideas at the Jewish Community Center of San Francisco|access-date=October 19, 2015}}</ref>

Kennedy graduated from [[St. Mary's High School (Phoenix, Arizona)|St. Mary's High School]] in [[Phoenix, Arizona]], and [[Arizona State University]]. item.title: Western world
item.description:
‎Other views: Unsourced. Seems like the author's own western-centric point of view.

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 186: Line 186:
   
 
Allegedly, definitions of the term "Western world" that some may consider "[[ethnocentric]]" others consider "[[social construction|constructed]]" around one or another Western culture. The British writer [[Rudyard Kipling]] wrote about this contrast: ''East is East and West is West and never the twain shall meet'', expressing his belief that somebody from the West "can never understand the Asian cultures" as the latter "differ too much" from the Western cultures. Some may view this alleged incompatibility as a precursor to Huntington's "[[Clash of Civilizations|clash of civilizations]]" theory.
  
Allegedly, definitions of the term "Western world" that some may consider "[[ethnocentric]]" others consider "[[social construction|constructed]]" around one or another Western culture. The British writer [[Rudyard Kipling]] wrote about this contrast: ''East is East and West is West and never the twain shall meet'', expressing his belief that somebody from the West "can never understand the Asian cultures" as the latter "differ too much" from the Western cultures. Some may view this alleged incompatibility as a precursor to Huntington's "[[Clash of Civilizations|clash of civilizations]]" theory.
−  
−
Paradoxically, today Asia and Africa to varying degrees may be considered quasi-Western. Many East Asians and South Asians and Africans and others associate or even identify with the cosmopolitan cultures and international societies referred to sometimes as Western. Likewise, many in the West identify with a transcultural humanity, a notion often found in visions of the sacred.
  
   
 
From a very different perspective, it has also been argued that the idea of the West is, in part, a non-Western invention, deployed in the non-West to shape and define non-Western pathways through or against modernity.<ref>Bonnett, A. 2004. ''The Idea of the West''</ref>
  
From a very different perspective, it has also been argued that the idea of the West is, in part, a non-Western invention, deployed in the non-West to shape and define non-Western pathways through or against modernity.<ref>Bonnett, A. 2004. ''The Idea of the West''</ref>

item.title: Revival (Selena Gomez album)
item.description:
‎Singles

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 73: Line 73:
 
"[[Good for You (song)|Good for You]]" was released as the album's lead single on June 22, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|author=Butan, Christina|url=http://www.people.com/article/selena-gomez-good-for-you-video|title=Selena Gomez Releases 'Good for You' Video|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=June 26, 2015|accessdate=June 27, 2015}}</ref> Gomez created anticipation for the release of the single by posting several teasers of the song on Instagram. The song was released to warm critical reception. It debuted at number nine on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], making it her third top 10 song on the chart and her highest charting debut.<ref name="Billboard Good For You debut">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6613247/wiz-khalifa-no-1-hot-100-selena-gomez-debuts|title=Wiz Khalifa No. 1 on Hot 100 'Again,' Selena Gomez Debuts at No. 9|work=Billboard}}</ref> "Good for You" has reached number five on the chart,<ref name="Selena Gomez US Hot 100">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/278617/Selena+Gomez/chart?f=379|title=Selena Gomez – Chart history|work=[[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] for Selena Gomez.}}</ref> making it her highest charting single. It sold 179,000 downloads in its first week, marking the first time Gomez topped the [[Digital Songs]] chart, and becoming her highest first-week sales of any of her songs.<ref name="Billboard Good For You debut"/> The song's video was released on June 26, 2015. In conclusion, the song also topped the US [[Mainstream Top 40]] chart in September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author=Trust, Gary|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6693364/selena-gomez-scores-first-pop-songs-no-1-with-good-for-you|title=Selena Gomez Scores First Pop Songs No. 1 With 'Good for You'|work=Billboard|date=September 14, 2015|accessdate=September 14, 2015}}</ref>

In early August, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' confirmed "[[Same Old Love]]" as the second single from the album.<ref name="Same Old Love confirmed 2nd single"/> On August 5, 2015, Gomez was at the first day of iHeartMedia's Music Summit where she played the song.<ref name="Billboard Same Old Love 2nd single from Revival, due Oct. 9"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/144176/hits-aplenty-at-day-one-of-iheartmedia-s-music-sum|title=Hits Aplenty At Day One Of iHeartMedia's Music Summit|work=All Access}}</ref> The song was made available for digital download with the pre-order of the album on September 9.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/selena-gomez-drops-new-single-same-old-love-2015109|title=Selena Gomez Drops New Single "Same Old Love" - Us Weekly|date=September 10, 2015|work=usmagazine.com}}</ref> The song features uncredited vocals from [[Charli XCX]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.directlyrics.com/world-premiere-selena-gomez-same-old-love-audio-review-news.html|title=World Premiere: Selena Gomez - "Same Old Love" [Audio / Review]|work=Directlyrics}}</ref> The music video was shot in downtown [[Los Angeles]] on August 15 and part of it was shot at the Revival event. Fans from the event appeared at the end of the video. The music video was released to [[Apple Music]] on September 22,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/post/idsa.77ecd15a-6168-11e5-bfec-e68e7c2338b2|title=It's here!! "Hands to Myself" is set to be released as the third single from ''Revival''.<ref name="hands">{{cite web|url=http://www.musictimes.com/articles/57228/20151207/selena-gomez-hands-myself-video-revival-sexy-watch.htm|title=Selena Gomez's 'Hands to Myself' Video Teaser: 'Revival' Singer Strips Down in Dangerous Clip|author=Menyes, Carolyn|work=[[Music Times]]|date=December 7, 2015|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref> A preview for its music video was revealed by Gomez on her Facebook account; however, no release date for the video and the single were announced.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Polanco|first1=Luis|title=Selena Gomez Can't Keep Her Hands to Herself In Sneak Peek of 'Hands to Myself' Video|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6786001/selena-gomez-hands-to-myself-video-preview|website=Billboard|publisher=billboard.com|accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref>
  
"Hands to Myself" is set to be released as the third single from ''Revival''.<ref name="hands">{{cite web|url=http://www.musictimes.com/articles/57228/20151207/selena-gomez-hands-myself-video-revival-sexy-watch.htm|title=Selena Gomez's 'Hands to Myself' Video Teaser: 'Revival' Singer Strips Down in Dangerous Clip|author=Menyes, Carolyn|work=[[Music Times]]|date=December 7, 2015|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref> A preview for its music video was revealed by Gomez on her Facebook account; however, no release date for the video and the single were announced.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Polanco|first1=Luis|title=Selena Gomez Can't Keep Her Hands to Herself In Sneak Peek of 'Hands to Myself' Video|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6786001/selena-gomez-hands-to-myself-video-preview|website=Billboard|publisher=billboard.com|accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref>

:[[User:Casliber|Cas Liber]] I saw that earlier, but thanks for notifying me. I didn't know I shouldn't add to that kind of page. I don't know what "transcluded" means. Does this mean one shouldn't add any comments to any GA review page if one is not a "reviewer"? Or is it because the article had already been promoted to GA status? I'm sorry. I don't know all the rules regarding GA or FA reviews. [[User:Corinne|Corinne]] ([[User talk:Corinne#top|talk]]) 19:33, 14 December 2015 (UTC)
  
:[[User:Casliber|Cas Liber]] I saw that earlier, but thanks for notifying me. I didn't know I shouldn't add to that kind of page. I don't know what "transcluded" means. Does this mean one shouldn't add any comments to any GA review page if one is not a "reviewer"? Or is it because the article had already been promoted to GA status? I'm sorry. I don't know all the rules regarding GA or FA reviews. [[User:Corinne|Corinne]] ([[User talk:Corinne#top|talk]]) 19:33, 14 December 2015 (UTC)
  +
::Ok, generally once an article is promoted then that process is closed. So I the case of [[Telopea_truncata]] it is now at FAC, so the page for article-related discussion germane to the FAC is at [[Wikipedia:Featured article candidates/Telopea truncata/archive1]]. But some people still use the article talk page, especially if they just have a few points. While the FAC is open, keeping discussion there helps the coordinators get an idea of the whole discussion. I got into FAC as it is the best way of ensuring stable/consensus versions - especially if wikipedia will at one point move from growth to maintenance phase. [[User:Casliber|Cas Liber]] ([[User talk:Casliber|talk]] '''·''' [[Special:Contributions/Casliber|contribs]]) 21:28, 14 December 2015 (UTC)

== Philanthropy ==
   
−
Lovell is a strong advocate for youth at risk and often centers her speaking upon the pressures facing youth and the power of youth voice.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ip|first1=Celina|title=Kelly Lovell helps youth discover their voice|url=http://www.coldlakesun.com/2015/05/27/kelly-lovell-helps-youth-discover-their-voice|website=Cold Lake Sun|accessdate=24 November 2015|date=27 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Young Canadian volunteers work to overcome age discrimination|url = http://thechronicleherald.ca/artslife/77090-young-canadian-volunteers-work-overcome-age-discrimination|website = The Chronicle Herald|publisher = |accessdate = 2015-12-14|last = Mehta|first = Diana|date = 2012-03-24}}</ref>

Lovell is a strong advocate for youth at risk and often centers her speaking upon the pressures facing youth and the power of youth voice.
   
−
At 19-years-old, Lovell founded Dollars for Dreams, a volunteer venture to raise money for [[Save the Children]]<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Young Canadian volunteers work to overcome age discrimination|url = http://thechronicleherald.ca/artslife/77090-young-canadian-volunteers-work-overcome-age-discrimination|website = The Chronicle Herald|publisher = https://plus.google.com/108608746427624408231|accessdate = 2015-12-14|last = Mehta|first = Diana|date = 2012-03-24}}</ref> and, in that same year, founded her company, Lovell Corporation.<ref name=":4">{{cite web|last1=A Joint Venture with WXN|title=Women in Power|url=http://business.financialpost.com/executive/executive-women/women-in-power-canadas-100-most-powerful-women|website=Financial Post|accessdate=14 November 2015}}</ref> As a speaker, Lovell often reflects upon the age discrimination she experienced during the start of her entrepreneurial and volunteer management career, urging leaders to listen and work with youth.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Young Canadian volunteers work to overcome age discrimination|url = http://thechronicleherald.ca/artslife/77090-young-canadian-volunteers-work-overcome-age-discrimination|website = The Chronicle Herald|publisher = https://plus.google.com/108608746427624408231|accessdate = 2015-12-14|last = Mehta|first = Diana|date = 2012-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Kelly Lovell challenges businesses to understand today's youth|url = http://www.insidehalton.com/news-story/5651805-kelly-lovell-challenges-businesses-to-understand-today-s-youth/|website = www.insidehalton.com|accessdate = 2015-12-14|last = Mitchell|first = Bob|publisher = Oakville Beaver|date = 2015-05-29}}</ref> Her social entrepreneurial venture, YOU Effect, is a global forum that particularly responds to this discrimination issue by offering opportunities for youth to creatively express their thoughts on a platform operated by their peers.<ref name=":2" />

item.title: Survival horror
item.description:
copyedit lead

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 2: Line 2:
 
{{VG Action}}
  
{{VG Action}}
   
−
'''Survival horror''' is a [[video game genres|subgenre]] of video games inspired by [[horror fiction]] that focuses on [[wikt:survival|survival]] of the character as the game tries to scare the player(s). Although combat can be a part of the gameplay, the player is made to feel less powerful than in typical action games, because of limited ammunition, health, speed, vision, or other limitations. The player is also challenged to find items that unlock the path to new areas, and solve puzzles at certain locations. Games make use of strong horror themes, and the player is often challenged to navigate dark maze-like environments, and react to unexpected attacks from enemies.
 +
'''Survival horror''' is a [[video game genres|subgenre]] of video games inspired by [[horror fiction]] that focuses on survival of the character as the game tries to frighten players. Although combat can be a part of the gameplay, the player is made to feel less in control than in typical action games through limited ammunition, health, speed and vision, or through various obstructions of the player's interaction with the [[game mechanics]]. The player is also challenged to find items that unlock the path to new areas and solve puzzles to proceed in the game. Games make use of strong horror themes, like dark maze-like environments and unexpected attacks from enemies.
   
−
The term "survival horror" was first used for the original Japanese release of ''[[Resident Evil (1996 video game)|Resident Evil]]'' in 1996 which was influenced by earlier games with a horror theme such as 1989's ''[[Sweet Home (video game)|Sweet Home]]''. The name has been used since then for games with similar gameplay, and has been retroactively applied to earlier titles. Starting with the release of ''[[Resident Evil 4]]'' in 2005, the genre began to incorporate more features from action games and more traditional first-person and third-person shooter games, which has led game journalists to question whether long-standing survival horror franchises and many recent popular horror franchises have abandoned the genre and moved into a different distinct genre often referred to as "action horror".<ref>{{cite web|title=Survival Horror vs. Action Horror|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/manifesto/survival-horror-vs-action-horror-10399|publisher=gamerevolution.com|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Evil Within preview – ‘real survival horror’|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/06/25/the-evil-within-preview-real-survival-horror-3855378/|publisher=metro.co.uk|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Horror Show - Survival Horror vs. Action Horror|url=http://www.zero1gaming.com/2013/05/01/survival-horror-vs-action-horror/|publisher=zero1gaming.com|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=6 Upcoming Horror Games That Look Absolutely Terrifying|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3229453/6-upcoming-horror-games-that-look-absolutely-terrifying/|publisher=blooody-disgusting.org|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref> Still, the survival horror genre has persisted in one form or another.
 +
The term "survival horror" was first used for the original Japanese release of ''[[Resident Evil (1996 video game)|Resident Evil]]'' in 1996 which was influenced by earlier games with a horror theme such as 1989's ''[[Sweet Home (video game)|Sweet Home]]''. The name has been used since then for games with similar gameplay, and has been retroactively applied to earlier titles. Starting with the release of ''[[Resident Evil 4]]'' in 2005, the genre began to incorporate more features from action games and more traditional [[first-person shooter|first person]] and [[third-person shooter]] games. This has led game journalists to question whether long-standing survival horror franchises and more recent franchises have abandoned the genre and moved into a different distinct genre often referred to as "action horror".<ref>{{cite web|title=Survival Horror vs. Action Horror|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/manifesto/survival-horror-vs-action-horror-10399|publisher=gamerevolution.com|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Evil Within preview – ‘real survival horror’|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/06/25/the-evil-within-preview-real-survival-horror-3855378/|publisher=metro.co.uk|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Horror Show - Survival Horror vs. Action Horror|url=http://www.zero1gaming.com/2013/05/01/survival-horror-vs-action-horror/|publisher=zero1gaming.com|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=6 Upcoming Horror Games That Look Absolutely Terrifying|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3229453/6-upcoming-horror-games-that-look-absolutely-terrifying/|publisher=blooody-disgusting.org|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref> Still, the survival horror genre has persisted in one form or another.

item.title: Chasing Shadows (album)
item.description:
← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 22: Line 22:
 
'''''Chasing Shadows''''' was [[The Comsat Angels]]' sixth album, released in 1986 on Island Records.
  
'''''Chasing Shadows''''' was [[The Comsat Angels]]' sixth album, released in 1986 on Island Records.
   
−
Having left [[Jive Records]], the band had gotten a recording contract with Island Records aided by [[Robert Palmer (singer)|Robert Palmer]], who confessed on a TV show to be a fan of the Comsat Angels.<ref>[http://www.renascent.co.uk/# the comsat angels, q&a]</ref> As a thank you, he was credited as "executive producer" on the album, and also provided vocals for the song "You'll Never Know."<ref>The Comsat Angels Q&A at [http://www.renascent.co.uk/ Renascent Records]</ref>
 +
Having left [[Jive Records]], the band had gotten a recording contract with Island Records, aided by [[Robert Palmer (singer)|Robert Palmer]], who confessed on a TV show to be a fan of the Comsat Angels.<ref>[http://www.renascent.co.uk/# the comsat angels, q&a]</ref> As a thank you, he was credited as "executive producer" on the album, and also provided vocals for the song "You'll Never Know."<ref>The Comsat Angels Q&A at [http://www.renascent.co.uk/ Renascent Records]</ref>
   
−
The track "The Cutting Edge" was released as a single, with "Something's Got to Give" on the b-side,<ref>[http://www.hotsdesign.co.uk/comsats/web.htm Comsat Angels website]</ref> a song which was not included on the album, but later appeared as a demo track on the 2007 release ''[[To Before]]''.<ref>[http://www.hotsdesign.co.uk/comsats/story2.htm Comsat Angels website]</ref> The original version appears on the 2015 reissue.
 +
The track "The Cutting Edge" was released as a single, with "Something's Got to Give" on the [[A-side and B-side|B-side,<ref>[http://www.hotsdesign.co.uk/comsats/web.htm Comsat Angels website]</ref>. The latter song was not included on the album, but later appeared as a demo track on the 2007 release ''[[To Before]]''.<ref>[http://www.hotsdesign.co.uk/comsats/story2.htm Comsat Angels website]</ref> The original version appeared on the 2015 reissue of ''Chasing Shadows''.
   
−
''Chasing Shadows'' was regarded by the band as a departure from their last two albums, ''[[Land (The Comsat Angels album)|Land]]'' and ''[[7 Day Weekend (album)|7 Day Weekend]]'', which were produced by [[Jive Records]]. During a 1997 interview, frontman [[Stephen Fellows|Steve Fellows]] agreed with a suggestion that ''Chasing Shadows'' offered his best vocals as an artist, adding: "I liked Rockfield, where we recorded ''Chasing Shadows'' cos it was very informal. We played mostly live, with vocals added later. ''[[Sleep No More (The Comsat Angels album)|Sleep No More]]'' was done live – the feel, capturing the moment. Obviously the Jive albums weren't done like that – assembled by machines in another room while we watched television and ate fruit." <ref>Step Off, interviews, Stephen Fellows interviewed by Tony Kinson 13/3/97 [http://www.comsatangels.net/]</ref>
 +
''Chasing Shadows'' was regarded by the band as a departure from their two prior albums, ''[[Land (The Comsat Angels album)|Land]]'' and ''[[7 Day Weekend (album)|7 Day Weekend]]'', which were produced by [[Jive Records]]. During a 1997 interview, frontman [[Stephen Fellows|Steve Fellows]] agreed with a suggestion that ''Chasing Shadows'' displayed his best vocal performance, adding: "I liked Rockfield, where we recorded ''Chasing Shadows'' cos it was very informal. We played mostly live, with vocals added later. ''[[Sleep No More (The Comsat Angels album)|Sleep No More]]'' was done live – the feel, capturing the moment. Obviously the Jive albums weren't done like that – assembled by machines in another room while we watched television and ate fruit." <ref>Step Off, interviews, Stephen Fellows interviewed by Tony Kinson 13/3/97 [http://www.comsatangels.net/]</ref>
   
−

item.title: Sol Invictus
item.description:
Removed a comma, added citation needed (incorrectly I think)

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 3: Line 3:
 
'''Sol Invictus''' ("Unconquered Sun") was the official [[Solar deity|sun god]] of the later [[Roman Empire]] and a patron of soldiers. In 274 AD the [[Roman emperor]] [[Aurelian]] made it an official [[cult (religious practice)|cult]] alongside the traditional Roman cults. Scholars disagree about whether the new deity was a refoundation of the ancient [[Latins (Italic tribe)|Latin]] cult of [[Sol (mythology)|Sol]],<ref>See S.E.Hijmans, "The sun that did not rise in the east", Babesch 71 (1996) p.115–150</ref> a revival of the cult of [[Elagabalus (deity)|Elagabalus]]<ref>See Gaston Halsberghe, "The cult of Sol Invictus", Leiden: Brill, 1972</ref> or completely new.<ref>As Hijmans states (p.115): "Scholars have consistently postulated a clear distinction between the Republican Sol Indiges and the Imperial Sol Invictus." and p.116 "We should keep in mind, however, that most scholars agree that this cult [Sol Indiges] was never important, and that it had disappeared altogether by the beginning of the second century AD"</ref> The god was favored by emperors after Aurelian and appeared on their coins until [[Constantine the Great|Constantine I]].<ref>Halsberghe, "The cult of Sol Invictus", p.155: "Up to the conversion of Constantine the Great, the cult of Deus Sol Invictus received the full support of the emperors. The many coins showing the sun god that these emperors struck provide official evidence of this." and p.169 "the custom of representing Deus Sol Invictus on coins came to an end in AD 323."</ref> The last inscription referring to Sol Invictus dates to AD 387,<ref>Halsberghe, "The cult of Sol Invictus", p.170 n.3: "CIL VI, 1778, dates from AD 387,"</ref> and there were enough devotees in the 5th century that [[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]] found it necessary to preach against them.<ref>Halsberghe, p.170, n.4: "Augustine, ''Sermones'', XII; also in ''Ennaratio in Psalmum'' XXV; ''Ennaratio'' II, 3."</ref>
  
'''Sol Invictus''' ("Unconquered Sun") was the official [[Solar deity|sun god]] of the later [[Roman Empire]] and a patron of soldiers. In 274 AD the [[Roman emperor]] [[Aurelian]] made it an official [[cult (religious practice)|cult]] alongside the traditional Roman cults. Scholars disagree about whether the new deity was a refoundation of the ancient [[Latins (Italic tribe)|Latin]] cult of [[Sol (mythology)|Sol]],<ref>See S.E.Hijmans, "The sun that did not rise in the east", Babesch 71 (1996) p.115–150</ref> a revival of the cult of [[Elagabalus (deity)|Elagabalus]]<ref>See Gaston Halsberghe, "The cult of Sol Invictus", Leiden: Brill, 1972</ref> or completely new.<ref>As Hijmans states (p.115): "Scholars have consistently postulated a clear distinction between the Republican Sol Indiges and the Imperial Sol Invictus." and p.116 "We should keep in mind, however, that most scholars agree that this cult [Sol Indiges] was never important, and that it had disappeared altogether by the beginning of the second century AD"</ref> The god was favored by emperors after Aurelian and appeared on their coins until [[Constantine the Great|Constantine I]].<ref>Halsberghe, "The cult of Sol Invictus", p.155: "Up to the conversion of Constantine the Great, the cult of Deus Sol Invictus received the full support of the emperors. The many coins showing the sun god that these emperors struck provide official evidence of this." and p.169 "the custom of representing Deus Sol Invictus on coins came to an end in AD 323."</ref> The last inscription referring to Sol Invictus dates to AD 387,<ref>Halsberghe, "The cult of Sol Invictus", p.170 n.3: "CIL VI, 1778, dates from AD 387,"</ref> and there were enough devotees in the 5th century that [[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]] found it necessary to preach against them.<ref>Halsberghe, p.170, n.4: "Augustine, ''Sermones'', XII; also in ''Ennaratio in Psalmum'' XXV; ''Ennaratio'' II, 3."</ref>
   
−
The idea, particularly popular in the 18th and 19th centuries, that the solstice date of 25 December for [[Christmas]] was selected because it was also the date of a [[Roman festival]] of ''Dies Natalis Solis Invicti'' (Birthday of the Unconquered Sun) is challenged by the church.<ref name=CofE/> Different explanations for the date similarity are considered to be "academically thoroughly viable hypotheses" by some.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6MXPEMbpjoAC&pg=PA88&dq=Roll+%22thoroughly+viable%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lv-WVPOlONLV7AbbgYGgDg&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Roll%20%22thoroughly%20viable%22&f=false Susan K. Roll, ''Toward the Origin of Christmas'' (Peeters Publications 1995 ISBN 978-90-3900531-6), p. 88]</ref> Both theories have supporters, with some claiming that the festival of ''Dies Natalis Solis Invicti'' was later [[Syncretism#Christianity|syncretized]] with Christmas, and others saying that the Christian celebration may predate the festival of the ''Dies Natalis Solis Invicti''.<ref>[http://www.academia.edu/968841/_Sol_Invictus_the_Winter_Solstice_and_the_Origins_of_Christmas_Mouseion_Number_47_3_2003_277-298 Steven Hijmans, "Sol Invictus, the Winter Solstice, and the Origins of Christmas" in ''Mouseion'', Number 47/3 (2003), pp. 384–385]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ognCKztR8a4C&pg=PA114&dq=Oxford+Companion+Thought+%22potentially+establishes%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=B5WaVOOQMIS17gaztYHYDg&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Oxford%20Companion%20Thought%20%22potentially%20establishes%22&f=false Karen B. Westerfield Tucker, "Christmas" in [[Adrian Hastings]], Alistair Mason, Hugh Pyper (editors), ''The Oxford Companion to Christian Thought'' (Oxford University Press 2000 ISBN 978-0-19860024-4), p. 124]</ref>
 +
The idea, particularly popular in the 18th and 19th centuries, that the solstice date of 25 December for [[Christmas]] was selected because it was also the date of a [[Roman festival]] of ''Dies Natalis Solis Invicti'' (Birthday of the Unconquered Sun) is challenged by the church.<ref name=CofE/> Different explanations for the date similarity are considered to be "academically thoroughly viable hypotheses" by some.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6MXPEMbpjoAC&pg=PA88&dq=Roll+%22thoroughly+viable%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lv-WVPOlONLV7AbbgYGgDg&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Roll%20%22thoroughly%20viable%22&f=false Susan K. Roll, ''Toward the Origin of Christmas'' (Peeters Publications 1995 ISBN 978-90-3900531-6), p. 88]</ref> Both theories have supporters, with some claiming that the festival of ''Dies Natalis Solis Invicti'' was later [[Syncretism#Christianity|syncretized]] with Christmas<ref>Citation needed</ref> and others saying that the Christian celebration may predate the festival of the ''Dies Natalis Solis Invicti''.<ref>[http://www.academia.edu/968841/_Sol_Invictus_the_Winter_Solstice_and_the_Origins_of_Christmas_Mouseion_Number_47_3_2003_277-298 Steven Hijmans, "Sol Invictus, the Winter Solstice, and the Origins of Christmas" in ''Mouseion'', Number 47/3 (2003), pp. 384–385]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ognCKztR8a4C&pg=PA114&dq=Oxford+Companion+Thought+%22potentially+establishes%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=B5WaVOOQMIS17gaztYHYDg&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Oxford%20Companion%20Thought%20%22potentially%20establishes%22&f=false Karen B. Westerfield Tucker, "Christmas" in [[Adrian Hastings]], Alistair Mason, Hugh Pyper (editors), ''The Oxford Companion to Christian Thought'' (Oxford University Press 2000 ISBN 978-0-19860024-4), p. 124]</ref>

::::That is a superb idea! I got really pissed off with people arguing about primary and secondary sources so I eventually sat down and wrote an essay about it.[[Wikipedia:Identifying primary and secondary sources for biology articles]] This gave me time and head-space to think about exactly what I wanted to say. It was cathartic to write it and really helped me deal with the frustration. It has not set the WP world on fire in terms of primary/secondary sources, but it is there if I wish to refer others to it. It shows others that you have thought really hard about subject. Great idea Trypto - hope you follow up on it SageRad and happy to help if you do.<span style="font-family:Segoe print; color:red; text-shadow:gray 0.2em 0.2em 0.4em;">DrChrissy</span> <sup><span style="font-family:Segoe print; color:red; text-shadow:gray 0.2em 0.2em 0.4em;">[[User talk:DrChrissy|(talk)]]</span></sup> 21:28, 14 December 2015 (UTC)

item.title: Karl-Heinz Steffens
item.description:
‎Career

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 49: Line 49:
 
Karl-Heinz Steffens studied clarinet with Ulf Rodenhäuser at the [[State University of Music and Performing Arts Stuttgart]] (1982-1985).<ref name="yafo">{{cite web|url=http://www.israel-opera.co.il/Eng/?CategoryID=263&ArticleID=374|title=Karl-Heinz Steffens, conductor|publisher=The Israeli Opera Tel-Aviv-Yafo|accessdate=2009-08-06}}</ref> After his first engagement as clarinettist at the [[Staatstheater Kassel]], Steffens became one of the world’s most highly regarded instrumentalists serving as Principal Clarinet at [[Frankfurt Opera]] (1985-1989), of the [[Bavarian Radio Symphony]] (1989-1996) and the [[Berlin Philharmonic]] (2001-2007) as well as maintaining an active solo career. <ref name="yafo" /> From 1996 to 1999 he taught at the [[Hochschule für Musik und Theater Hannover|University of Music and Drama Hanover]].<ref name="yafo" /> In 2001 he was appointed Professor in Clarinet by the [[Hanns Eisler School of Music Berlin|Hochschule für Musik Hanns Eisler Berlin]] where he taught until 2008.<ref name="yafo" />
  
Karl-Heinz Steffens studied clarinet with Ulf Rodenhäuser at the [[State University of Music and Performing Arts Stuttgart]] (1982-1985).<ref name="yafo">{{cite web|url=http://www.israel-opera.co.il/Eng/?CategoryID=263&ArticleID=374|title=Karl-Heinz Steffens, conductor|publisher=The Israeli Opera Tel-Aviv-Yafo|accessdate=2009-08-06}}</ref> After his first engagement as clarinettist at the [[Staatstheater Kassel]], Steffens became one of the world’s most highly regarded instrumentalists serving as Principal Clarinet at [[Frankfurt Opera]] (1985-1989), of the [[Bavarian Radio Symphony]] (1989-1996) and the [[Berlin Philharmonic]] (2001-2007) as well as maintaining an active solo career. <ref name="yafo" /> From 1996 to 1999 he taught at the [[Hochschule für Musik und Theater Hannover|University of Music and Drama Hanover]].<ref name="yafo" /> In 2001 he was appointed Professor in Clarinet by the [[Hanns Eisler School of Music Berlin|Hochschule für Musik Hanns Eisler Berlin]] where he taught until 2008.<ref name="yafo" />
   
−
In 2007 Karl-Heinz Steffens relinquished his post as Principal Clarinet of the [[Berlin Philharmonic]]<ref name="Principal Clarinet of the Berlin Philharmonic">{{cite web|url=http://www.karlheinzsteffens.com/#!biografie/qivba|title=Principal Clarinet of the Berlin Philharmonic|publisher=Karl-Heinz Steffens|accessdate=2015-12-11}}</ref> and his international solo career to devote himself to conducting and to take up the position as General Music Director of the Staatskapelle and Opera Halle (2007-2013).<ref name="General Music Director of the Staatskapelle and Opera Halle">{{cite web|url=http://www.karlheinzsteffens.com/#!biografie/qivba|title=General Music Director of the Staatskapelle and Opera Halle|publisher=Karl-Heinz Steffens|accessdate=2015-12-11}}</ref> Karl-Heinz Steffens’ conducting career has developed at a remarkable pace. Only two years later, at the start of the 2009/10 season, he took up a further appointment as Music Director of the [[Staatsphilharmonie Rheinland-Pfalz|Deutsche Staatsphilharmonie Rheinland-Pfalz]] in Ludwigshafen.<ref name="Deutsche Staatsphilharmonie Rheinland-Pfalz" />
 +
In 2007 Karl-Heinz Steffens relinquished his post as Principal Clarinet of the [[Berlin Philharmonic]]<ref name="Principal Clarinet of the Berlin Philharmonic">{{cite web|url=http://www.karlheinzsteffens.com/#!biografie/qivba|title=Principal Clarinet of the Berlin Philharmonic|publisher=Karl-Heinz Steffens|accessdate=2015-12-11}}</ref> and his international solo career to devote himself to conducting and to take up the position as General Music Director of the [[Staatskapelle Halle|Staatskapelle]] and [[Halle Opera House|Opera Halle]] (2007-2013).<ref name="General Music Director of the Staatskapelle and Opera Halle">{{cite web|url=http://www.karlheinzsteffens.com/#!biografie/qivba|title=General Music Director of the Staatskapelle and Opera Halle|publisher=Karl-Heinz Steffens|accessdate=2015-12-11}}</ref> Karl-Heinz Steffens’ conducting career has developed at a remarkable pace. Only two years later, at the start of the 2009/10 season, he took up a further appointment as Music Director of the [[Staatsphilharmonie Rheinland-Pfalz|Deutsche Staatsphilharmonie Rheinland-Pfalz]] in Ludwigshafen.<ref name="Deutsche Staatsphilharmonie Rheinland-Pfalz" />
   
 
Since then Karl-Heinz Steffens is in huge demand as a guest conductor internationally. The past two seasons have seen his debuts with the [[Berlin Philharmonic]]<ref name="Berlin Philharmonic: Karl-Heinz Steffens conducts Beethoven, Zimmermann and Schubert">{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalconcerthall.com/en/concert/16915|title=Berlin Philharmonic: Karl-Heinz Steffens conducts Beethoven, Zimmermann and Schubert|publisher=Berlin Philharmonic Digital Concert Hall|accessdate=2013-10-11}}</ref>, [[Munich Philharmonic]], [[Vienna Symphony]]<ref name="Karl-Heinz Steffens debütiert er am Pult der Wiener Symphoniker im Musikverein">{{cite web|url=https://www.musikverein.at/monatszeitung/artikel_im_pdf.php?artikel_id=1724|title=Poesie und Präzision: Karl-Heinz Steffens debütiert er am Pult der Wiener Symphoniker im Musikverein|publisher=Magazin der Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde in Wien|accessdate=2014-12-14}}</ref>, [[Philharmonia Orchestra]] London, [[Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France]], Danish Radio, Helsinki Philharmonic and Zurich [[Tonhalle Orchestra]]. Steffens regularly appears with orchestras such as the [[City of Birmingham Symphony]], the [[Bournemouth Symphony]], and the [[Hallé]] in the UK, the [[Bamberg Symphony]], [[Dresden Philharmonic]], and the Radio Symphony orchestras of Berlin, Cologne, Frankfurt, Hamburg, Leipzig and Stuttgart. This season Karl-Heinz Steffens will make his debuts with the [[Teatro Regio]] in Torino, the [[Gulbenkian Orchestra]] in Lisbon, the orchestra of [[Maggio Musicale Fiorentino]] in Florence, the [[Royal Stockholm Philharmonic]], and returns to the [[Orchestre Philharmonique de Monte Carlo]] and Radio France.
  
Since then Karl-Heinz Steffens is in huge demand as a guest conductor internationally. The past two seasons have seen his debuts with the [[Berlin Philharmonic]]<ref name="Berlin Philharmonic: Karl-Heinz Steffens conducts Beethoven, Zimmermann and Schubert">{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalconcerthall.com/en/concert/16915|title=Berlin Philharmonic: Karl-Heinz Steffens conducts Beethoven, Zimmermann and Schubert|publisher=Berlin Philharmonic Digital Concert Hall|accessdate=2013-10-11}}</ref>, [[Munich Philharmonic]], [[Vienna Symphony]]<ref name="Karl-Heinz Steffens debütiert er am Pult der Wiener Symphoniker im Musikverein">{{cite web|url=https://www.musikverein.at/monatszeitung/artikel_im_pdf.php?artikel_id=1724|title=Poesie und Präzision: Karl-Heinz Steffens debütiert er am Pult der Wiener Symphoniker im Musikverein|publisher=Magazin der Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde in Wien|accessdate=2014-12-14}}</ref>, [[Philharmonia Orchestra]] London, [[Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France]], Danish Radio, Helsinki Philharmonic and Zurich [[Tonhalle Orchestra]]. Steffens regularly appears with orchestras such as the [[City of Birmingham Symphony]], the [[Bournemouth Symphony]], and the [[Hallé]] in the UK, the [[Bamberg Symphony]], [[Dresden Philharmonic]], and the Radio Symphony orchestras of Berlin, Cologne, Frankfurt, Hamburg, Leipzig and Stuttgart. This season Karl-Heinz Steffens will make his debuts with the [[Teatro Regio]] in Torino, the [[Gulbenkian Orchestra]] in Lisbon, the orchestra of [[Maggio Musicale Fiorentino]] in Florence, the [[Royal Stockholm Philharmonic]], and returns to the [[Orchestre Philharmonique de Monte Carlo]] and Radio France.

item.title: Spam blog
item.description:
← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 1: Line 1:
 
{{about|blogs designed to host spam|spamming made through comments in legitimate blogs|spam in blogs}}
  
{{about|blogs designed to host spam|spamming made through comments in legitimate blogs|spam in blogs}}
   
−
A '''spam blog''', sometimes referred to by the [[neologism]] '''splog''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/14.09/splogs.html |title=Wired 14.09: Spam + Blogs = Trouble. Splogs are the latest thing in online scams |publisher=Wired.com |date=2009-01-04 |accessdate=2010-05-14}}</ref> is a [[blog]] which the author uses to promote affiliated websites, to increase the search engine rankings of associated sites or to simply sell links/ads.
 +
A '''spam blog''', also known as an auto blog or the [[neologism]] '''splog''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/14.09/splogs.html |title=Wired 14.09: Spam + Blogs = Trouble. Splogs are the latest thing in online scams |publisher=Wired.com |date=2009-01-04 |accessdate=2010-05-14}}</ref> is a [[blog]] which the author uses to promote affiliated websites, to increase the search engine rankings of associated sites or to simply sell links/ads.
   
 
The purpose of a splog can be to increase the [[PageRank]] or backlink portfolio of affiliate websites, to artificially inflate paid ad impressions from visitors (see [[Scraper site|made for AdSense]] or MFA-blogs), and/or use the blog as a link outlet to sell links or get new sites indexed. Spam blogs are usually a type of [[scraper site]], where content is often either [[inauthentic text]] or merely stolen (see ''[[blog scraping]]'') from other websites. These blogs usually contain a high number of [[hyperlink|link]]s to sites associated with the splog creator which are often disreputable or otherwise useless websites.
  
The purpose of a splog can be to increase the [[PageRank]] or backlink portfolio of affiliate websites, to artificially inflate paid ad impressions from visitors (see [[Scraper site|made for AdSense]] or MFA-blogs), and/or use the blog as a link outlet to sell links or get new sites indexed. Spam blogs are usually a type of [[scraper site]], where content is often either [[inauthentic text]] or merely stolen (see ''[[blog scraping]]'') from other websites. These blogs usually contain a high number of [[hyperlink|link]]s to sites associated with the splog creator which are often disreputable or otherwise useless websites.

item.description:
Notification: speedy deletion nomination of Nirvana Chaudhary. (TW)

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:28, 14 December 2015
Line 1: Line 1:
  +
  +
==[[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion|Speedy deletion]] nomination of [[:Nirvana Chaudhary]]==
  +
[[File:Information icon4.svg|48px|left|alt=|link=]]
  +
{{Quote box|quote=<p>If this is the first article that you have created, you may want to read [[WP:Your first article|the guide to writing your first article]].</p><p>You may want to consider using the [[Wikipedia:Article wizard|Article Wizard]] to help you create articles.</p>|width=20%|align=right}}
  +
A tag has been placed on [[:Nirvana Chaudhary]], requesting that it be speedily deleted from Wikipedia. This has been done under [[WP:CSD#G4|section G4 of the criteria for speedy deletion]], because the page appears to be a repost of material that was previously deleted following a [[Wikipedia:Deletion debates|deletion debate]], {{#if:|at [[{{{2}}}]]|such as at [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion|articles for deletion]]}}. Under the specified criteria, where a page has substantially identical content to that of a page deleted after debate, and any changes in the content do not address the reasons for which the material was previously deleted, it may be deleted at any time.
  +
  +
If you think this page should not be deleted for this reason, you may '''contest the nomination''' by [[:Nirvana Chaudhary|visiting the page]] and clicking the button labelled "Contest this speedy deletion". This will give you the opportunity to explain why you believe the page should not be deleted. However, be aware that once a page is tagged for speedy deletion, it may be removed without delay. Please do not remove the speedy deletion tag from the page yourself, but do not hesitate to add information in line with [[Wikipedia:List of policies|Wikipedia's policies and guidelines]]. If the page is deleted, and you wish to retrieve the deleted material for future reference or improvement, then please contact the deleting administrator, or if you have already done so, you can place a request [[WP:RFUD|here]]. <!-- Template:Db-repost-notice --> <!-- Template:Db-csd-notice-custom --> [[User:Smartse|SmartSE]] ([[User talk:Smartse|talk]]) 21:28, 14 December 2015 (UTC)
